text: Turbid brown pour with min head. Huge rye, whisky, dark malt nose, thick and rich flavor and tongue, oak, huge rye, oaky spirits, warming heat, hops. A delicious beer.

750 c&c from Cap Tap. Loud cork pop! Pours darkly ruddy with a creamy beige or light tan head. Lots of rye in the aroma. And some whisky (BYB, whiskey is supposed to be reserved for Irish Whiskey). Near full bodied. Flavor is rye, fruit, whisky, and moderately roasty malt. Heat isnt an issue for me. Dang, but it is smooth rye and whisky. Maybe a hint of astringent oak creeps through. This is deadly stuff. Quaffable perhaps. Do not drink the whole thing and drive! Not very bitter, but the rye spice (tho this rye doesnt seem all that spicy as I expected - maybe the ABV is affecting me) covers that gap. Wonderful stuff.
750ml bottle pours a brown color with a bit of frothy head. Bit of rye spice. Very hot. Whisky overpowers.

750 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 11/11/2016. Pours slightly hazy/cloudy deep ruby red, light copper/brown color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big caramel, brown sugar, toffee, raisin, plum, fig, date, cherry, apricot, apple, red grape, vanilla, spicy rye whiskey, toasted oak, and brown bread; with lighter notes of maple, molasses, coconut, chocolate, cocoa, and yeast/oak/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/bready/rye malt, fruity yeast, and rye whiskey barrel notes; with great strength. Minimal booziness in the aromas as it warms. Taste of huge caramel, brown sugar, toffee, raisin, plum, fig, date, cherry, apricot, apple, red grape, vanilla, spicy rye whiskey, toasted oak, and brown bread; with lighter notes of maple, molasses, coconut, chocolate, cocoa, and yeast/oak/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate rye/whiskey/oak spiciness and light earthy hop bitterness on the finish. Lingering notes of huge caramel, brown sugar, toffee, dark fruit, cherry, apricot, apple, red grape, vanilla, spicy rye whiskey, toasted oak, brown bread, maple, coconut, light chocolate/cocoa, and yeast/oak/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready/rye malt, fruity yeast, and rye whiskey barrel flavors; with an awesome malt/spiciness balance, and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light dryness from rye/whiskey/oak spiciness and carbonation, lightly increasing through the glass. Medium-plus carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, creamy/bready/grainy, and lightly slick/sticky/chalky/tannic balanced mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is extremely well hidden; a mild increasing warmth, with zero barrel booziness lingering after the finish. Overall this is an amazing barrel aged imperial rye ale. All around incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready/rye malt, fruity yeast, and rye whiskey barrel flavors; very smooth and dangerously easy to sip on for the huge ABV. Pretty much perfectly balanced on all flavors, and great barrel presence without being boozy. Basically an English barleywine on flavor profile. A highly delicious offering.

draft in snifter that poured a dark brown with beige head. aroma was booze, dark roasted malts, sweet spice of the rye and dark fruit almost had the scent of a barley wine. the taste was strong, sweet from the dark fruit aspect spicy rye and boozy strong a definite sipper. bold strong flavors all over the tongue. amazing beer and you only need one. super boozy

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, murky brown pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of big sweet raisin, dark fruit, rye notes, some whiskey into some cocoa, some slight further dark fruits. Taste was a mix of caramel, toffee, dark fruits into vanilla, oak, and lots of whiskey, rye notes with a touch of spice, finishing sweet, slightly dry. Well done.

Bottle served in a glass, 
this ale was a dark brown in the glass with some haze and particles, the pour gave almost a fingers worth of off-white cover of bubbles that lowered quickly, it left some spots and small fingers of lacing that rolled off quickly, 

there were malty aromas with rye, whiskey liquor, rye spice and grain, liquor vanilla, caramel, toasted malt and grain, some dark bread, faint wood, a little earth, brown sugar and liquor sweetness, 

it had flavors of rye grain, whiskey, liquor, vanilla, caramel, toasted grain, toasted dark bread, rye spice, a bit of dark fruit (raisin and fig) in the background, there was a whiskey liquor prick with some spice bite at the finish, 

this drink felt pretty full on the mouth, there was soft to less than average carbonation and it was a little creamy on the lips, each sip gave some warmth on the mouth and throat, 

there was lots of whiskey and liquor on the nose and in the flavor, 
the rye and rye spice was noticed throughout the drink.

Bottle from I dont remember where. Pours a deep amber ruby color with a small tan head. Nose is a nice hit of spicy rye, rye whiskey, vanilla, oak, and bread. Flavor is similar with spicy rye, rye whiskey, slight booze, and vanilla. Finish lingers with rye and mild boozy oak. Delicious overall- a nice take on this beer with legit rye presence.

Deep mahogany pour with a one finger, creamy beige head. Aroma is caramel, rye, cocoa nibs, licorice, spicy and bitter rye, savory toasted grain, toasted oak. Flavor is rye, oak, raw sugar, caramel, light earthy wood, toffee and a hint of licorice. Medium to heavy body, chewy entry, medium carbonation, off dry finish. Really good, maybe a bit plain tasting.
UPDATED: APR 18, 2017 Mother of Pearl this is sooooo good. Malt, Malt, Malt. Booze, Booze, Booze. How do you make anything this dam good! Ask Boulevard. SOB this is fanfriggingtastic!
Rich beer. Brown with ample head but disappears to nothing. Whiskey wood notes. Rye is quite noticable, but with a little sweetness. Pretty good.

Morrom avermelhado, de média turbidez, espuma bege de média formaçao e persistência. Aroma maltado, alcoólico, whisky bastante aparente. Paladar de médio dulçor, sem amargor. Corpo licoroso e baixa carbonatação. Final bastante alcoólico, amadeirado, maçã.

Ruby-amber color with a bit of white head. Sweet, malty, apple notes, malty with a booze edge. 

Notes: On tap at One Lile House NYC (Apt 17)

750mL c&c poured into Engelszell glass. Dark ruby brown color. Khaki head. Aroma is spirit without the bite. A light cherry and creamy maltiness. Flavor not big. Light cherry creamy malt. Woodsy. Lightly bitter end.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Pours a murky orange-brown with a foamy khaki head that settles to a partial film on top of the beer. Foamy rings of lace line the glass on the drink down. Smell is of toasted malt, caramel, toffee, rye whisky, and wood aromas. Taste is much the same with caramel, toffee, vanilla, coconut, rye whisky, and wood flavors on the finish. There is a mild amount of bitterness and an alcohol kick on the palate with each sip. This beer has a good level of carbonation with a crisp and sticky mouthfeel. Overall, this is a very good beer with fantastic rye whisky characteristics from the double barrel aging used on this one.

From notes. Enjoyed with Doug at his place on March 22. 750 mL bottle. The pour is a darker ruby brown with a thicker light tan head and a couple spots of lace as it falls down. The aroma is heavy rye. The spiciness is pretty huge. A light caramel malt and a light alcoholic burn on the back end. This smells like a scotch ale. The flavor is really interesting. There is a huge spiciness to it. Its sweet and lightly malty. I like the rye control to it. Its like a spicy Backwoods Bastard. The mouth feel is a little lighter and brightly carbonated with a lingering spiciness to it and a strong barrel. Its a really interesting beer.
Dark sweet tea color. Rye tastes gives way to a whiskey finish. Would love to try this without the whiskey barrels.
Tastes not unlike a rye Old Fashioned, which is no bad thing. Terrific rye spice supporting toffee, toast, wood and such.
Pours a dark clear amber with white head. A strong oak, vanilla and rum aroma. A strong rye taste with dark alcohol, caramel malts, oak and vanilla. A lingering scotch and oaky aftertaste.

Uber, Seattle. Thick off white tan foam. Dark, heavy malty brown, rich and thick. Autumnal spiced aroma, cinnamon and nutmeg. Thick, rich body. Heavy booze. Spicy alcohol burn at the finish. Smooth and rich. Tasty.
B. Pours a murky brown color with khaki head. Has a lot of good flavor, dry finish.
On tap at Mirror Twin. Aroma is heavily rye, as expected, also plenty of alcohol and vanilla components.

On Draught
Pours a reddish mahogany with a small but well retained head & good lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is rich & sweet with lots of vanilla & bourbon. Lightly woody & full of toffee & light cocoa.

The aroma is sort of like bourbon soaked tootsie rolls, plenty of vanilla & a little chocolate. Nice caramel character with plenty of sweetness, but it never crosses the line into cloying. Lightly woody with some pear like fruit notes. Complex and huge... plenty boozy. 
 
Maybe not something I should luv, but I do.
750 ml bottle cork and caged. Big whiskey nose. Muddy brown color. Whiskey, caramel, some sweetness, very smooth. Yes, please.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a gold brown with a one finger head. Aroma is big vanilla, oak, barrel. Taste is vanilla/oak throughout followed with a smokey char and malt. It has big whiskey notes throughout the entire taste - the double barrel aging definitely shows through. Mouthfeel is medium with moderate carbonation. Overall, I think this is one of the best beers in Boulevards portfolio. Definitely worth seeking out during its annual release.

Taste: Bold woody, oak, bourbon, rye malts, warming mouth-feel, brown sugar notes. Sweet bourbon, oak, barley grain nose. Amber/brown, semi opaque, with a tan delicate head. Medium/Full body. Complex smooth, yet boozy for those cold winter days. 33 IBUs

A deep medium-dark brown, not much head to speak of. Aroma is something special... vanilla, whiskey, malt, maybe some dark cherry. Strong rye whiskey on the taste... moderately boozy, heavy malt, heavy vanilla. Found it fizzier than I expected.
On draft at Trio in Kill Devil Hills NC it is cloudy Amber color with a slight head. The aroma is toffee and the taste is strong hints of caramel and a lot of booziness
On draft at Trio in Kill Devil Hills NC. Pours aromas of caramel and banana esters. Flavors of toffee. Huge boozy finish.

Keg at World of Beer Charlottesville, 3/29/16. Clear orange, thin creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of rye, citrus, toasted malt. The taste is strong rye, strong citrus, caramel, toasted malts. Medium bodied, moderate tartness.

2016 Philly Beer Week draft @ Strangeloves. Pours amber color with a touch of red. Creamy, 1-finger white head. Aroma of peppery, grassy ryemixed with a note of whiskey. Full body, lightly syrupy. Mild boozy astringency to the finish. Caramel malt flavor mixed with a peppery note that lies beneath flavors of whiskey and vanilla oak.
Boozy aroma with hints of dark fruit. Complex flavors up front. As beer warms up complexity increases in a good way. Get a rid home after this one....very good.

This brew is exceptional. The aroma is of pungent raisin, alcohol and smooth whisky essence. The malty and spiciness is well balanced and in the subtle semi-sweet caramel recipe. The palate finishes quite pleasant and the lingering taste is wonderful. There is a bit of soft leather, and well balanced on the tip of the entry. Well done! The only problem is that is not yet bottled.: draft/growler only.
Cloudy brown thin beige head; aroma is whisky hint of sweet malt; flava is sweet malt strong whisky and alcohol notes throughout ; feels medium no fizz; finishes tangy sweet with grassy liquor notes

Draft at the Gnarly Barley. Pours hazy copper with a fizzy beige head. Tastes like sweet candied malt, dried fruits, booze, raisins, woody. Light/medium body and low carbonation. Smells like booze, sweet candied malt, dried fruits, raisins, woody.
Sampler pours black with a brown head. Aroma of oak, bourbon, spices, chocolate and coffee. Taste is bourbon, coffee and chocolate.

Full pour at Asbury. This is a lightly hazy deep brown with a touch of red and a tall khaki head. The aroma is powerful and boozy, but in a pleasant way. Genuine, complex whisky notes are all over this guy with modest hopping and assertive spicy rye character. The palate is huge and alcohol burn is more than approachable as a slow sipper. Heavy whisky notes come through and not just as blunt oak or vanilla. We get mature wood flavors with a really deep rye body. Bitterness is wonderfully balanced. Its pretty close to sipping a fine rye whisky but with the body and smoother alcohol of a beer.

On tap. Slightly hazy dark amber copper pour with small tan head. Aroma of rye, malts, grains, vanilla oak and bourbon. Taste of spicy rye grains, vanilla, malts, caramel, oak, bourbon and then more rye! Full bodied, medium carbonation, big and boozy, nice peppery rye finish, delicious!

Draft at Bailey's Range. As the bartender poured she described it as "booze on booze on booze" pours brown with no real head. Doesn't leave much lacing. Nice whiskey barrel on the nose. Lots of whiskey on the tongue along with the spiciness of the rye. Finished clean. Hides it's booze really well. Quite lovely. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The beer pours light copper with a lot of murkiness and very little head. The aroma is super malty with caramel, cream, oak and vanilla. Super rich and delightful. It has a full body with fairly sharp carbonation. The usage is drier than the aroma, but still rich. There is grainy oak, spicy rye and some alcohol added to the mix. The finish has almost a root beer spice and more alcohol heat. Pretty nice.

4 oz mini goblet draft at Bier Station in Kansas City, Missouri. The pour is a hazed brown mahogany with a tan foamy head. The aroma is warming alcohol, wood and spicey rye. As the beer warms, an inviting sweet cream malt is present. The taste is big bold rye spice right away, warm alcohol, and sweet malts. Almost tastes like a (really well crafted) beer cocktail. The rye and booze are integrated pretty well. The palate is medium bodied with soft carbonation and the warming alcohol spice rye in the dry finish. Well done, perfectly executed concept - just not up my personal alley.
On draught. Pours brown with a minimal khaki head. Nose is rye whisky. Taste is malt sweetness up front with a nice rye whisky finish. Very smooth and hides the high ABV well. Delicious.
Tap at Grizzlys. Murky dull orange pour with minor head. Big boozy whiskey notes with some caramel sweetness. Quite good.
Aromas of vanilla, caramel, some whiskey, subtle chocolate, toast. Murky red-brown with a fully fading off-white head. Pretty dry, boozy, loads of whiskey flavors. Medium bodied.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., dispensed to a snifter displaying a slightly hazed, amber/walnut color, with a modest layer of off white head foam that produced a persistent ring & film, with some dots & dashes of light lacing. The aroma was ready alcohol/whiskey, some caramel sweetness to the aged Barleywine scent, with some barrel & apple wood hints. Medium+ bodied, with fair but appropriate carbonation, alcohol warmth led the flavor barrage, with moderate rye spice, and earthy bitterness taking on lesser, but complementary roles. A fine sipper that exuded some pleasant cellar-like maturity in the taste.

On tap at Patricks, St Peter, MN. Pours a hazy dark amber color with small off-white head. Aroma is full of rye bread, vanilla, bourbon, and dark fruit. Taste is boozy and sweet, with some bitterness in the finish. Body is medium to full with average carbonation. What a process, ending in over-the-top results, pushing the envelope of barrel-aged beers. I wasnt expecting anything over-the-top in a bar in my small hometown, but this made me say WOW and helped make the weekend memorable.
Draft at Meridian Pint. Hazy to cloudy ambee color, bright white head. Aroma of toasted rye bread. Taste is boozy sice. Decent.

dark amber pour with a thick head that fades to a cap. aroma is rye bread, caramel and light woody hop Initial light body rolls into toffee and bready sweetness. peppery rye, light floral/woody hop finish with lingering spice

On tap at Frisco Taphouse and Brewery in Columbia, MD. 

Hazy, rusty amber-brown with a thin, pale khaki head and good lacing. 

Aroma of caramel, dates, raisins, vanilla, acetone, whiskey, oak and rye. 

Taste of oak, whiskey, rye, caramel, plums and dates. 

Full/medium body and medium carbonation with a solid mouthfeel that lets you know you are drinking a meal. 

Okay, it's alcoholic; it's still good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft on gust tap, Brickway in Omaha. Color is Amber brown, very little head. The aroma is rye grain, whiskey, oak, more whiskey and yep, rye. Flavor is what they say it is. Plenty of whiskey, oak and rye. A mild spicy kick in the finish. This is damn nice with a huge process.

4th of flight of 4 (listed in menu, served, tasted all in same order) @ worldofbeer Evanston. beautiful clear reddish amber color, luxurious vanilla nose, boozy, intense, very sweet, creamy. loved the concept. this is the way to have rye. well, this or neat. i guess i like the outer reaches.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2016 4 oz pour on draft at ChurchKey during the Victory 20th anniversary event. Shared by SlopeSurfer, thanks Kevin! Clear dark amber with off-white head. Aromas of nail polish, whiskey, oak. Tastes of whiskey, oak, light acetone, a little coconut. Medium body with a dry finish. Love Rye-on-Rye and most Boulevard beers but this is just too much for me.
Lots of caramelized malt, booze and surprisingly, rye. Dark mahogany pour. Not my cup of tea. Syrupy consistency. Tap at churchkey thanks to slopesurfer
On tap at Martin City Pub. Comes a mostly clear amber with a decent beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and whiskey. Taste is malt, rye, caramel, whiskey, and wood. Very enjoyable!

Threes a crowd with Boulevards Rye-on-Rye-on-Rye. Is it one rye too many? No, but Boulevards Rye-ception doesnt add all that much too an already-strong brew. If anything theres a bit more rye whiskey burn and more pronounced wood notes. Still a lot of tasty caramel. One things for sure, at 14.6% this one will mess you up right and proper in high enough quantities. Definitely fun to drink for the experience.

Draft/Fest.

A- Oak, sweet.

A- Amber color, cloudy liquid, off white head.

T- Oak, subtle rye, slightly sweet.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, balanced finish.

O- Glad I got to be the first rate! While its overall a good beer, it doesnt match the regular rye on rye. This one didnt seem to have the body or the rye in general that the base beer does.
